Type.Name: Window

TypeSignature.Value: public class Window : Gtk.Bin, Implementor, IWrapper, IWrapper, IDisposable

Type.ThreadSafetyStatement: Gtk# is thread aware, but not thread safe; See the Gtk# Thread Programming for details.

Docs.summary: Toplevel widget which can contain other widgets.
Docs.remarks: Toplevel widget which can contain other widgets.

Docs.summary: Returns a list of all existing toplevel windows.

remarks.para: The widgets in the list are not individually referenced. If you want to iterate through the list and perform actions involving callbacks that might destroy the widgets, you must call g_list_foreach (result, (GFunc)g_object_ref, ) first, and then unref all the widgets afterwards.

MemberSignature.Value: public void BeginMoveDrag (int button, int root_x, int root_y, uint timestamp);

Docs.param: Mouse button that initiated the drag.
X position where the user clicked to initiate the drag, in root window coordinates.
Y position where the user clicked to initiate the drag.
Timestamp from the click event that initiated the drag.

remarks.para: This method is used if an application has window movement grips. When GDK can support it, the window movement will be done using the standard mechanism for the window manager or windowing system. Otherwise, GDK will try to emulate window movement, potentially not all that well, depending on the windowing system.

MemberSignature.Value: public void GetFrameDimensions (out int left, out int top, out int right, out int bottom);

Docs.summary: Retrieves the dimensions of the frame window for this toplevel.
Docs.param: Location to store the width of the frame at the left, or .
Location to store the height of the frame at the top, or .
Location to store the width of the frame at the returns, or .
Location to store the height of the frame at the bottom, or .

remarks.para: It will not return the size of the window border drawn by the window manager, which is the normal case when using a windowing system. See to get the standard window border extents.) See also , .
Note: this is a special-purpose function intended for the framebuffer port; see .

Docs.summary: Asks to iconify (i.e. minimize) the specified .

remarks.para: Note that you shouldn't assume the window is definitely iconified afterward, because other entities (e.g. the user or window manager) could deiconify it again, or there may not be a window manager in which case iconification isn't possible, etc. But normally the window will end up iconified. Just do not write code that crashes if not.
You can track iconification via the signal on .

Docs.summary: Asks to unstick window, which means that it will appear on only one of the user's desktops.

remarks.para: Note that you shouldn't assume the window is definitely unstuck afterward, because other entities (e.g. the user or window manager) could stick it again. But normally the window will end up stuck. Just do not write code that crashes if not.
You can track stickiness via the signal on .

Note that you shouldn't assume the window is definitely unmaximized afterward, because other entities (e.g. the user or window manager) could maximize it again, and not all window managers honor requests to unmaximize. But normally the window will end up unmaximized. Just don't write code that crashes if not.
You can track maximization via the signal on .

MemberSignature.Value: public void GetSize (out int width, out int height);

remarks.para: If window is not onscreen, it returns the size GTK+ will suggest to the window manager for the initial window size (but this is not reliably the same as the size the window manager will actually select). The size obtained by is the last size received in a GdkEventConfigure, that is, GTK+ uses its locally-stored size, rather than querying the X server for the size. As a result, if you call then immediately call , the size would not have taken effect yet. After the window manager processes the resize request, GTK+ receives notification that the size has changed via a configure event, and the size of the window gets updated.

Note 1: Nearly any use of this function creates a race condition, because the size of the window may change between the time that you get the size and the time that you perform some action assuming that size is the current size. To avoid race conditions, connect to on the window and adjust your size-dependent state to match the size delivered in the GdkEventConfigure.

MemberSignature.Value: public void GetDefaultSize (out int width, out int height);

Docs.summary: Gets the default size of the window.
Docs.param: Location to store the default width, or .
Location to store the default height, or .

remarks.para: A value of -1 for the width or height indicates that a default size has not been explicitly set for that dimension, so the "natural" size of the window will be used.

MemberSignature.Value: public void Resize (int width, int height);
public void SetFrameDimensions (int left, int top, int right, int bottom);
public void AddMnemonic (uint keyval, Gtk.Widget target);
public void BeginResizeDrag (Gdk.WindowEdge edge, int button, int root_x, int root_y, uint timestamp);
public void GetPosition (out int root_x, out int root_y);
public bool MnemonicActivate (uint keyval, Gdk.ModifierType modifier);
public void RemoveMnemonic (uint keyval, Gtk.Widget target);
public void SetWmclass (string wmclass_name, string wmclass_class);
public void SetDefaultSize (int width, int height);

Docs.summary: Sets the default size of an object, with the specified width and height arguments.

remarks.para: It is used for setting the default size an object will have. The first argument, int width, defines the default width of the object ( in pixels ). A similar situation happens with the second argument, int height.
It only affects the initial size of the Window, so the user can resizes it. If the Window is hidden and re-shown, it will remmeber the size it had before get hidding.

MemberSignature.Value: public void Move (int x, int y);

Docs.summary: Sets the position for a Window, based on the Gtk.WindowPosition position argument.
Docs.param: To be added: an object of type 'Gtk.WindowPosition'

remarks.para: Is is used for placing the Window in some area, depending on the Gtk.WindowPosition position argument.

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetGeometryHints (Gtk.Widget geometry_widget, Gdk.Geometry geometry, Gdk.WindowHints geom_mask);

Docs.summary: Disposes the resources associated with the object.

Docs.returns: An instance of Window, wrapping the C object.

remarks.para: This is an internal constructor, and should not be used by user code.

Docs.summary: Creates a new Window object, based on the Gtk.WindowType type argument.

remarks.para: Creates a new Window object, wich can be of type TopLevel ( most of the cases ) or PopUp. Take care with the use of PopUp type, since it is not controlled by the window manager.

Docs.remarks: This is an internal constructor, and should not be used by user code.

Docs.summary: Creates a new TopLevel Window object, with the specified string argument as the title.

remarks.para: Creates a new TopLevel Window object, using the string title argument to specify the Window title. You get the same if you use the public Window ( Gtk.WindowType type ) constructor and later set the string Title property.

MemberSignature.Value: public static GLib.List DefaultIconList { set; get; };

Docs.summary: Sets if a Window will be decorated or not ( borderless ).

remarks.para: With this property you control if a window will be decorated or not.

By default, windows are decorated with a title bar and resize controls. Some window managers allow to disable these decorations, creating a borderless Window. If you set this property as false, Gtk# will try to convince the window manager not to decorate the Window.

Docs.summary: Sets if a Window will be resizable by the user or not.

remarks.para: By default, windows are resizable, so you can change the size of them. But if you set this property to false, the user won't be able to change the size of them.

Docs.summary: Property used for setting/getting the window position.

remarks.para: This property will alow you to define where a Window must be displayed on the screen. It work with the Gtk.WindowPosition enum, soy maybe you should check it before use it.

Docs.summary: Property used for defining the default height of a window.

remarks.para: This property will allow you to define the default height for your Window. It only define the default one, so if the Window is resized, it won't be able to do anything.

Docs.summary: Property used for setting the Window Title.

remarks.para: This property will allow you to set the Window Title. The Title of a window will be displayed in its title bar. Since the title bar is rendered by the window managers on X Window System, the way it appears will depend on the user preferences. This title should help the users to distinguish a window from others opened. A good title will have the application name an the actual document, for example.

Docs.returns: Creates a new instance of Window, using the GLib-provided type

remarks.para: This is a constructor used by derivative types of that would have their own GLib type assigned to it. This is not typically used by C# code.
